ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: It varied from week to week with some being under 2 hours and some being closer to 4 if we had presentations.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Strengths: trip to Haiti Weaknesses: Bad use of class time. Not enough discussion, time to work on projects

Course was great exposure to chronic disease in another context and enabled interdisciplinary work. Class time was not always productive, but did introduce interesting speakers and topics relating to Haiti
Even though messy in terms of syllabus, when looking back on this course, I feel like I have learnt a lot on very different scales.
Great experience in development work, but only marginal new concepts learned.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Gordon Geballe  Has a great heart. Could have been more structure to the class.

Instructor: Gordon Geballe  Very knowledgeable and great at introducing forestry to students with little to no background. Made a strong effort to provide students with comprehensive background on Haiti by bringing in different speakers.
Instructor: Gordon Geballe  Professor Geballe is very approachable and definitely gave to the course an interesting approach.
Instructor: Gordon Geballe  Gordon is a caring and passionate teacher.

Instructor: Gordon Geballe  He is a great man--kind, patient, caring, with a good sense of humor. However, my only wish is that he was a bit more structured. He did not seem to take that much ownership of the class at times.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: You get out of it what you put into it. We were very interested in our project so we worked a lot on maximizing our findings and investing the time. The time spent in Haiti will be wonderful and an eye-opening experience.
An interesting course on how, as developed country citizens we can help 'developing' countries, how our acts are perceived and how each side perceives the collaboration at stake.
YES! Was a great, transformative experience.
